title: Containers
text: simulation performed using Apptainer/Singularity manctmed.sif image file. image linux container manCTMed package dependencies pre-installed. build Apptainer/Singularity image file (manctmed.sif), run following. NOTE: complete reproducibility software stack, actual manctmed.sif used simulations can requested maintainer GitHub repository.
code: apptainer pull manctmed.sif docker://ijapesigan/manctmed:latest

title: Containers
text: facilitate exploration package, created Docker container based Rocker Project. manCTMed package dependencies pre-installed can accessed browser using Rstudio IDE.

title: Containers
text: launch Rstudio Server, run following. Open http://localhost:8787 web browser launch Rstudio Server. username: rstudio password: yourpassword
code: docker run --rm -ti -e PASSWORD=yourpassword -p 127.0.0.1:8787:8787 ijapesigan/manctmed

title: Illustration 1 - Direct, Indirect, and Total Effects

what: Extract Elements of the Drift Matrix and the Process Noise Covariance Matrix
title: Illustration 1 - Direct, Indirect, and Total Effects
text: extract elements drift matrix process noise covariance matrix fit object.
code: # drift matrix phi <- matrix(   data = coef(fit)[     c(       "phi_11",       "phi_21",       "phi_31",       "phi_12",       "phi_22",       "phi_32",       "phi_13",       "phi_23",       "phi_33"     )   ],   nrow = 3 ) # column names and row names are needed to define the indirect effects colnames(phi) <- rownames(phi) <- c(   "conflict",   "knowledge",   "competence" ) # process noise covariance matrix sigma <- matrix(   data = coef(fit)[     c(       "sigma_11",       "sigma_12",       "sigma_13",       "sigma_12",       "sigma_22",       "sigma_23",       "sigma_13",       "sigma_23",       "sigma_33"     )   ],   nrow = 3 )

what: Direct, Indirect, and Total Effects of a Time Interval of Three
title: Illustration 1 - Direct, Indirect, and Total Effects
text: Using Med function cTMed package, direct, indirect, total effects time interval three given .
code: Med(   phi = phi,   from = "conflict",   to = "competence",   med = "knowledge",   delta_t = 3 ) #>  #> Total, Direct, and Indirect Effects #>  #>      interval   total  direct indirect #> [1,]        3 -0.1004 -0.0914  -0.0089

what: Direct, Indirect, and Total Effects of a Time Interval of Zero to Ten

title: Illustration 2 - Confidence Intervals for the Direct, Indirect, and Total Effects
text: object fit contains fitted dynr model. Data generated using manCTMed::IllustrationGenData function. model fitted using manCTMed::IllustrationFitDynr.

title: Illustration 2 - Confidence Intervals for the Direct, Indirect, and Total Effects
code: # drift matrix phi <- matrix(   data = coef(fit)[     c(       "phi_11", "phi_21", "phi_31",       "phi_12", "phi_22", "phi_32",       "phi_13", "phi_23", "phi_33"     )   ],   nrow = 3 ) # column names and row names are needed to define the indirect effects colnames(phi) <- rownames(phi) <- c(   "conflict",   "knowledge",   "competence" ) # process noise covariance matrix sigma <- matrix(   data = coef(fit)[     c(       "sigma_11", "sigma_12", "sigma_13",       "sigma_12", "sigma_22", "sigma_23",       "sigma_13", "sigma_23", "sigma_33"     )   ],   nrow = 3 ) # measurement error covariance matrix theta <- matrix(   data = coef(fit)[     c(       "theta_11", 0, 0,       0, "theta_22", 0,       0, 0, "theta_33"     )   ],   nrow = 3 ) # initial condition mu0 <- coef(fit)[   c(     "mu0_1", "mu0_2", "mu0_3"   ) ] sigma0 <- matrix(   data = coef(fit)[     c(       "sigma0_11", "sigma0_12", "sigma0_13",       "sigma0_12", "sigma0_22", "sigma0_23",       "sigma0_13", "sigma0_23", "sigma0_33"     )   ],   nrow = 3 )

what: Sampling Variance-Covariance Matrix of Parameter Estimates
title: Illustration 2 - Confidence Intervals for the Direct, Indirect, and Total Effects
code: # combining the drift matrix and the process noise covariance matrix phi_sigma_names <- c(   "phi_11", "phi_21", "phi_31",   "phi_12", "phi_22", "phi_32",   "phi_13", "phi_23", "phi_33",   "sigma_11", "sigma_12", "sigma_13",   "sigma_22", "sigma_23",   "sigma_33" ) vcov_theta <- vcov(fit)[phi_sigma_names, phi_sigma_names] phi_names <- c(   "phi_11", "phi_21", "phi_31",   "phi_12", "phi_22", "phi_32",   "phi_13", "phi_23", "phi_33" ) vcov_phi_vec <- vcov_theta[phi_names, phi_names]

what: Parametric Bootstrap Method Confidence Intervals For The Direct, Indirect, and Total Effects
title: Illustration 2 - Confidence Intervals for the Direct, Indirect, and Total Effects
text: parametric bootstrap approach involves generating data parametric model fitting model generated data multiple times. data generation model fitting hadled bootStateSpace package. estimated parameters passed arguments PBSSMOUFixed function bootStateSpace package, generates parametric bootstrap sampling distribution parameter estimates. argument R specifies number bootstrap replications. generated data model estimates stored path using specified prefix file names. ncores = parallel::detectCores() argument instructs function use available CPU cores system. NOTE: Fitting CT-VAR model multiple times computationally intensive. Using BootMed function cTMed package, confidence intervals direct, indirect, total effects time interval one, two, three given .

code: # drift matrix phi <- matrix(   data = coef(fit)[     c(       "phi_11", "phi_21", "phi_31",       "phi_12", "phi_22", "phi_32",       "phi_13", "phi_23", "phi_33"     )   ],   nrow = 3 ) # column names and row names are needed to define the indirect effects colnames(phi) <- rownames(phi) <- c(   "conflict",   "knowledge",   "competence" ) # process noise covariance matrix sigma <- matrix(   data = coef(fit)[     c(       "sigma_11", "sigma_12", "sigma_13",       "sigma_12", "sigma_22", "sigma_23",       "sigma_13", "sigma_23", "sigma_33"     )   ],   nrow = 3 ) # measurement error covariance matrix theta <- matrix(   data = coef(fit)[     c(       "theta_11", 0, 0,       0, "theta_22", 0,       0, 0, "theta_33"     )   ],   nrow = 3 ) # initial condition mu0 <- coef(fit)[   c(     "mu0_1", "mu0_2", "mu0_3"   ) ] sigma0 <- matrix(   data = coef(fit)[     c(       "sigma0_11", "sigma0_12", "sigma0_13",       "sigma0_12", "sigma0_22", "sigma0_23",       "sigma0_13", "sigma0_23", "sigma0_33"     )   ],   nrow = 3 )

what: Sampling Variance-Covariance Matrix of Parameter Estimates
title: Illustration 3 - Regions of Significance
code: # combining the drift matrix and the process noise covariance matrix phi_sigma_names <- c(   "phi_11", "phi_21", "phi_31",   "phi_12", "phi_22", "phi_32",   "phi_13", "phi_23", "phi_33",   "sigma_11", "sigma_12", "sigma_13",   "sigma_22", "sigma_23",   "sigma_33" ) vcov_theta <- vcov(fit)[phi_sigma_names, phi_sigma_names] phi_names <- c(   "phi_11", "phi_21", "phi_31",   "phi_12", "phi_22", "phi_32",   "phi_13", "phi_23", "phi_33" ) vcov_phi_vec <- vcov_theta[phi_names, phi_names] # range of time intervals delta_t <- sort(   c(     0:10,     seq(from = 0, to = 10, length.out = 1000)   ) )

what: Delta Method Confidence Intervals For The Direct, Indirect, and Total Effects
title: Illustration 3 - Regions of Significance
text: Using DeltaMed function cTMed package, confidence intervals direct, indirect, total effects long sequence time interval values generated. makes regions significance visible. Consider using ncores argument use multiple cores delta_t vector long. plot method DeltaMed presents regions significance visually represented shaded areas plot.
code: delta <- DeltaMed(   phi = phi,   vcov_phi_vec = vcov_phi_vec,   delta_t = delta_t,   from = "conflict",   to = "competence",   med = "knowledge",   ncores = parallel::detectCores() ) plot(delta)

what: Monte Carlo Method Confidence Intervals For The Direct, Indirect, and Total Effects
title: Illustration 3 - Regions of Significance
text: Using MCMed function cTMed package, confidence intervals direct, indirect, total effects long sequence time interval values generated. makes regions significance visible. Consider using ncores argument use multiple cores delta_t vector long. plot method MCMed presents regions significance visually represented shaded areas plot.
code: mc <- MCMed(   phi = phi,   vcov_phi_vec = vcov_phi_vec,   delta_t = delta_t,   from = "conflict",   to = "competence",   med = "knowledge",   R = 20000L,   ncores = parallel::detectCores(), # use multiple cores   seed = 42 ) plot(mc)

what: Parametric Bootstrap Method Confidence Intervals For The Direct, Indirect, and Total Effects
title: Illustration 3 - Regions of Significance
text: parametric bootstrap approach involves generating data parametric model fitting model generated data multiple times. data generation model fitting hadled bootStateSpace package. estimated parameters passed arguments PBSSMOUFixed function bootStateSpace package, generates parametric bootstrap sampling distribution parameter estimates. argument R specifies number bootstrap replications. generated data model estimates stored path using specified prefix file names. ncores = parallel::detectCores() argument instructs function use available CPU cores system. NOTE: Fitting CT-VAR model multiple times computationally intensive. Using BootMed function cTMed package, confidence intervals direct, indirect, total effects long sequence time interval values generated. makes regions significance visible. Consider using ncores argument use multiple cores delta_t vector long. plot method BootMed presents regions significance visually represented shaded areas plot.
code: R <- 1000L path <- root$find_file(   ".setup",   "data-raw" ) prefix <- "illustration_pb" phi_hat <- phi sigma_hat <- sigma boot <- PBSSMOUFixed(   R = R,   path = path,   prefix = prefix,   n = 133,   time = 101,   delta_t = 0.10,   mu0 = mu0,   sigma0_l = t(chol(sigma0)),   mu = c(0, 0, 0),   phi = phi,   sigma_l = t(chol(sigma)),   nu = c(0, 0, 0),   lambda = diag(3),   theta_l = t(chol(theta)),   mu0_fixed = FALSE,   sigma0_fixed = FALSE,   ncores = parallel::detectCores(),   seed = 42,   clean = FALSE ) pb <- BootMed(   phi = extract(object = boot, what = "phi"), # extracts the bootstrap drift matrices   phi_hat = phi_hat,   delta_t = delta_t,   from = "conflict",   to = "competence",   med = "knowledge",   ncores = parallel::detectCores() ) plot(pb) plot(pb, type = "bc") # bias-corrected

code: pb <- BootMedStd(   phi = extract(object = boot, what = "phi"), # extracts the bootstrap drift matrices   sigma = extract(object = boot, what = "sigma"), # extracts the bootstrap process noise covariance matrices   phi_hat = phi_hat,   sigma_hat = sigma_hat,   delta_t = delta_t,   from = "conflict",   to = "competence",   med = "knowledge",   ncores = parallel::detectCores() ) plot(pb) plot(pb, type = "bc")

title: Illustration Small Scale Simulation Results — illustration_results
text: 22 columns: taskid Task ID. replications Number replications. effect Total, direct, indirect effect. interval Time interval. parameter Population parameter. method Method used generate confidence intervals. xmy Logical. TRUE x m y path. std Logical. TRUE standardized. FALSE unstandardized. est Mean parameter estimate. se Mean standard error. z Mean \(z\) statistic. p Mean \(p\)-value. R Number Monte Carlo bootstrap replications. ll Mean lower limit 95% confidence interval. ul Mean upper limit 95% confidence interval. sig Proportion statistically significant results. zero_hit Proportion replications confidence intervals included zero. theta_hit Proportion replications confidence intervals included population parameter. sq_error Mean squared error. se_bias Bias standard error estimate. coverage Coverage probability. power Statistical power.

title: Simulation Results — results
code: data(results)

title: Simulation Results — results
text: dataframe 24 columns: taskid Task ID. replications Number replications. effect Total, direct, indirect effect. interval Time interval. dynamics Dynamics. 0 original drift matrix, -1 near-neutral dynamics, 1 stronger damping. parameter Population parameter. method Method used generate confidence intervals. xmy TRUE, mediation model \(X \M \Y\). FALSE, mediation model \(Y \M \X\). std TRUE, standardized total, direct, indirect effects. FALSE, unstandardized total, direct, indirect effects. n Sample size. est Mean parameter estimate. se Mean standard error. z Mean \(z\) statistic. p Mean \(p\)-value. R Number Monte Carlo replications. ll Mean lower limit 95% confidence interval. ul Mean upper limit 95% confidence interval. sig Proportion statistically significant results. zero_hit Proportion replications confidence intervals contained zero. theta_hit Proportion replications confidence intervals contained population parameter. sq_error Mean squared error. se_bias Bias standard error estimate. coverage Coverage probability. power Statistical power.
